sen.j: 田沼 意次（たぬま おきつぐ）は、江戸時代中期の武士・大名。
sen.e: Okitsugu TANUMA was a samurai and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) in the middle of the Edo period.
Okitsugu TANUMA was a samurai and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) of the middle Edo period.
Okitsugu TANUMA was a samurai and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) of the middle Edo period.

sen.j: 遠江国相良藩の初代藩主である。
sen.e: He was the first load of the Sagara domain of the Totomi province.
He was the first lord of the Sagara domain of Totomi province.
He was the first lord of the Sagara domain of Totomi province.

sen.j: 相良藩田沼家初代。
sen.e: He was the first head of the Tanuma family of the Sagara domain.
He was also the first head of the Tanuma family of the Sagara domain.
He was also the first head of the Tanuma family of the Sagara domain.

sen.j: 享保4年（1719年）7月27日、田沼意行の長男として江戸の田安屋敷で生まれる。
sen.e: He was born as the first son of Okiyuki TANUMA in the Tanuma residence in Edo on July 27, 1719.
He was born in the Tanuma residence in Edo as the first son of Okiyuki TANUMA on July 27, 1719.
He was born in the Tayasu residence in Edo as the first son of Okiyuki TANUMA on July 27, 1719.
sen.cmt: 田安屋敷なのでTayasuとしました。

sen.j: 幼名は龍助。
sen.e: His childhood name was Ryuusuke.
His childhood name was Ryusuke.

sen.j: 父・意行は紀州藩の足軽だったが、第8代征夷大将軍の徳川吉宗に登用され小身旗本となった。
sen.e: His father Okiyuki was an ashigaru (common foot soldier) of the Kishu domain, but Okitsugu was appointed to a humble direct retainer of the shogun by the eighth Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo), Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.

His father Okiyuki was an ashigaru (common foot soldier) of the Kishu domain, but Okitsugu was appointed as a humble direct retainer to the shogun by the eighth Seii Taishogun (Barbarian-Subduing Generalissimo), Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.

His father Okiyuki was an ashigaru (common foot soldier) of the Kishu domain, but Okitsugu was appointed as a humble direct retainer to the shogun by the eighth Seii Taishogun (Barbarian-Subduing Generalissimo), Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 意次は第9代将軍となる徳川家重の西丸小姓として抜擢され、享保20年（1735年）に父の遺跡600石を継ぐ。
sen.e: Okitsugu was assigned to a Nishimaru pageboy of Ieshige TOKUGAWA, the ninth shogun, and succeeded the remains of his father of 600 koku in 1735.
Okitsugu was selected as the Nishimaru pageboy to Ieshige TOKUGAWA, the ninth shogun, and inherited 600 koku on his father's death in 1735.
Okitsugu was selected as the Nishinomaru (west compound of the Edo castle) pageboy to Ieshige TOKUGAWA, the ninth shogun, and inherited the stipend of 600 koku of rice on his father's death in 1735.
sen.cmt: 西丸、遺跡の訳を変えました。

sen.j: 意次は父・意行が当時としては老齢になってから生まれた息子だった。
sen.e: Okitsugu was born when his father Okiyuki attained an advanced age.
When Okitsugu was born, his father Okiyuki was already quite advanced in age.
When Okitsugu was born, his father Okiyuki was already quite advanced in age for becoming a father in those days.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 意行は息子を授かるために七面大明神に帰依し、そして意次が生まれた。
sen.e: Okiyuki worshipped Shichimen-daimyojin to be blessed with a son, and Okitsugu was born..
sen.cmt: 七面大明神は、Shichimen-daimyojinとしました。
sen.e: Okiyuki worshipped Shichimen-daimyojin, hoping to be blessed with a son, and Okitsugu was born.
Okiyuki worshipped Shichimen-daimyojin, hoping to be blessed with a son, and Okitsugu was born.

sen.j: そのため意次は七面大明神に感謝し、家紋を七曜星に変更したといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that Okitsugu thanked Shichimen-daimyojin greatly and changed his family crest to shichiyosei.
It is said that Okitsugu was very grateful to Shichimen-daimyojin for this and changed his family crest to the shichiyosei (a symbol of the goddess).
It is said that Okitsugu was very grateful to Shichimen-daimyojin for this and changed his family crest to the the seven luminaries (with one central circle surrounded by six other circles).
sen.cmt: 七曜星の訳を変えました。

tit.e: Period of the lord of the Sagara domain
Years as lord of the Sagara domain
Years as lord of the Sagara domain

sen.j: 元文2年（1737年）、従五位主殿寮になり、延享2年（1745年）には家重の将軍就任に伴って本丸に仕える。
sen.e: He became jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) Tonomoryo (Bureau of Grounds) in 1737 and served in the Honmaru (castle keep) when Ieshige assumed shogun in 1745.
He became a jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) Tonomoryo (Bureau of Grounds) in 1737, and served in the Honmaru (castle keep) when Ieshige became shogun in 1745.
He became a junior-fifth-rank official of the Imperial Palace Keeper's Bureau in 1737, and served in the castle keep when Ieshige became shogun in 1745.

sen.j: 寛延元年（1748年）に1,400石を加増され、宝暦5年（1755年）には更に3,000石を加増され、その後家重によって宝暦8年（1758年）に起きた美濃国八幡藩の一揆（郡上一揆）に関する裁判にあたらせるために、御側御用取次から1万石の大名に取り立てられた。
sen.e: He was given additional 1,400 koku in 1748 and additional 3,000 koku in 1755, and was promoted from an attendant official business toritsugi (an attendant who served Shogun by informing of a visitor and convey the message) to a daimyo of 10000 koku by Ieshige TOKUGAWA to judge the uprising (Gujo ikki) that occurred in the Yawata domain of the Mino province in 1758.

He was given an additional 1,400 koku in 1748 and another 3,000 koku in 1755; he was also promoted from an attendant official-business toritsugi (an attendant who served the Shogun by informing him of visitors and conveying messages) to a daimyo with 10000 koku by Ieshige TOKUGAWA in order to judge the 1758 uprising (Gujo ikki) in the Yawata domain of Mino province.

He was given an additional fief of 1,400 koku of rice in 1748 and another 3,000 koku in 1755; he was also promoted from a shogunate attendant to informing him of visitors and conveying messages (toritsugi) to a feudal lord (daimyo) with a fief of 10000 koku of rice by Ieshige TOKUGAWA in order to judge the 1758 uprising in the Hachiman domain of Mino province (the Gujo uprising).
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 宝暦11年（1761年）、家重が死去した後も、世子の第10代将軍徳川家治の信任は厚く、破竹の勢いで昇進し、明和4年（1767年）にはさらに5,000石加増、御用人から側用人へと出世し従四位に進み2万石の相良城主となって、明和6年（1769年）には侍従にあがり老中格になる。
sen.e: Even after the death of Ieshige in 1761, Okitsugu was trusted by the 10th shogun Ieharu TOKUGAWA, heir of Ieshige, was promoted quickly, given additional 5,000 koku, became sobayonin (lord chamberlain) from Goyonin (officer handling domestic economy) and then became Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank), became the lord of Sagara Castle with a fief of 20000 koku, and was promoted to jiju (chamberlain) and roju (senior councilor).

Even after Ieshige's death in 1761, Okitsugu was trusted by the 10th shogun, Ieharu TOKUGAWA, Ieshige's heir; he was promoted quickly, given additional 5,000 koku, promoted from Goyonin (officer handling domestic economy) to Sobayonin (lord chamberlain), advanced to Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank), became lord of Sagara Castle with a fief of 20,000 koku, and was promoted to jiju (chamberlain) and roju (senior councilor).

Even after Ieshige's death in 1761, Okitsugu was trusted by the 10th shogun, Ieharu TOKUGAWA, Ieshige's heir; he was promoted quickly, given an additional fief of 5,000 koku of rice, promoted from an officer in charge of general affairs and accounts (goyonin) to a shogunate chamberlain (sobayonin), advanced to the junior fourth rank, became the lord of Sagara Castle with a fief of 20,000 koku, and was promoted to a grand chamberlain (jiju) and a senior councilor (roju).
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 安永元年（1772年）、相良藩5万7,000石の大名に取り立てられ、老中を兼任し、前後10回の加増で僅か600石の旗本から5万7,000石の大名にまで昇進し、側用人から老中になった初めての人物となった。
sen.e: He was assigned to a daimyo of the Sagara domain with a fief of 57,000 koku, doubled as roju and was given 10 additional fiefs, i.e., he was promoted from a bakufu hatamoto (direct retainer of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) with a fief of 600 koku to a daimyo with a fief of 57,000 koku and he was the first person who became roju from sobayonin (lord chamberlain).

He was appointed daimyo of Sagara domain with a fief of 57,000 koku, also served as roju and was given 10 additional fiefs; in other words, he was promoted from a bakufu hatamoto (a direct retainer of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) with a fief of 600 koku to a daimyo with a fief of 57,000 koku, and was the first person to be promoted from sobayonin (lord chamberlain) to roju.

He was appointed feudal lord (daimyo) of Sagara domain with a fief of 57,000 koku of rice, also served as a senior councilor (roju) and was given 10 additional fiefs; in other words, he was promoted from a shogunate direct retainer (hatamoto) with a fief of 600 koku to a feudal lord (daimyo) with a fief of 57,000 koku, and was the first person to be promoted from a shogunate chamberlain (sobayonin) to a senior councilor (roju).
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: この頃より老中首座である松平武元など意次を中心とした幕府の閣僚は、数々の幕政改革を手がけ、田沼時代と呼ばれる権勢を握る。
sen.e: The Cabinet members of the bakufu, including Okitsugu and Takechika MATSUDAIRA, who was the head of roju, began reformation of the shogunate government and gained the reins of power so that this period was called the Tanuma period.

The Cabinet members of the bakufu, including Okitsugu and Takechika MATSUDAIRA, the head of roju, began to reform the shogunate government and took the reins of power, with the result that this period was called the Tanuma period.

The cabinet members of the shogunate government, including Okitsugu and Takechika MATSUDAIRA, the head of roju, began to reform the government and took the reins of power, with the result that this period was called the Tanuma period.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 悪化する幕府の財政赤字を食い止めるべく、重商主義政策を採る。
sen.e: The bakufu adopted a Mercantilism policy to eliminate its budget deficit that was increasing.
The bakufu adopted a policy of mercantilism to eliminate its budget deficit, which had been on the rise.
The shogunate government adopted a policy of mercantilism to bring down the accumulated budget deficit.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 内容は株仲間の結成、銅座などの専売制の実施、鉱山の開発、蝦夷地の開発計画、俵物などの専売による外国との貿易の拡大、下総国印旛沼の干拓に着手する等の政策を実施した。
sen.e: They carried out such policies as formation of kabunakama (merchant guild), monopolization of Doza (a place where copper was cast and dealt in business during the Edo period), development of mines, development plan of Ezochi (inhabited area of Ainu), expansion of foreign trades by monopolization of goods in straw bags, and reclamation of the Inba marsh in the Shimosa province.

They executed policies such as the formation of the kabunakama (merchant guild), the monopolization of Doza (a place where copper was cast and dealt in business during the Edo period), mine development, the Ezochi development plan (an area inhabited by Ainu; current Hokkaido), the expansion of foreign trade by monopolization of goods in straw bags, and the reclamation of the Inba marsh in Shimosa province.

They executed policies such as the formation of trade guilds (kabunakama), the monopoly system of the copper guild and so on, mine development, the Ezo (current Hokkaido) development plan, the expansion of foreign trade by exclusive selling of sea products (dried sea cucumber, dried abalone, and shark-fin), and the reclamation of the Inba marsh in Shimosa province.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: その結果、幕府の財政は改善に向かい、景気もよくなった。
sen.e: As a result, the financial affairs improved and business recovered.
As a result, finances improved and business recovered.
As a result, finances improved and business recovered.

sen.j: しかし、社会の初期資本主義化によって、町人・役人の生活が金銭中心のものとなり、そのために事実として賄賂が横行した。
sen.e: However, the life of townspeople and officials was based on money due to the initial capitalism of the society and bribes were rampant.
However, due to this early capitalism of their society, the lives of the townspeople and officials became focused on money, and bribes were rampant.
However, due to this early capitalism of their society, the lives of the townspeople and officials became focused on money, and bribes were rampant.

sen.j: また、都市部で町人の文化が発展する一方、益の薄い農業で困窮した農民が田畑を放棄し、都市部へ流れ込んだために農村の荒廃が生じた。
sen.e: While the culture of townspeople developed in urban areas, farmers who were reduced to poverty due to non-profitable agriculture abandoned their fields and drifted into cities, thus ruining agricultural communities.

While the culture of townspeople developed in urban areas, farmers who had been reduced to poverty by non-profitable agriculture abandoned their fields and drifted into cities, thus ruining agricultural communities.

While the culture of townspeople developed in urban areas, farmers who had been reduced to poverty by non-profitable agriculture abandoned their fields and drifted into cities, thus ruining agricultural communities.

sen.j: 印旛沼運河工事の失敗や江戸の火事・浅間山の大噴火などの災害の勃発、疲弊した農村部に天明の大飢饉と呼ばれる食糧難や疫病が生じた。
sen.e: The canal work in the Inba marsh failed, disasters, such as fires in Edo and large-scale eruption of Mt. Asama, occurred, and the Tenmei Famine took place in weakened rural areas, causing food shortage and epidemics.

The canal work in the Inba marsh failed, disasters such as fires in Edo and a large-scale eruption of Mt. Asama occurred, and the Tenmei Famine took place in weakened rural areas, causing food shortages and epidemics.

The canal work in the Inba marsh failed, disasters such as fires in Edo and a large-scale eruption of Mt. Asama occurred, and the Tenmei Famine took place in weakened rural areas, causing food shortages and epidemics.

sen.j: 意次は対策を打ち出すが、失敗し逆に事態を悪化させてしまった。
sen.e: Okitsugu took measures, but failed and worsened the state of affairs.
Okitsugu took measures, but these failed and ended up making the situation worse.
Okitsugu took measures, but these failed and ended up making the situation worse.

sen.j: その中にあって財政難に陥っていた諸藩は米価の値上がりを借金返済の機会とし、検地により年貢の取立てを厳しくしていった。
sen.e: The domains that were in financial difficulties took advantage of higher rice price to pay off their debt and collect the land tax more strictly.
Domains with financial difficulties took advantage of the higher rice prices to pay off their debts and collect land taxes more strictly.
Domains with financial difficulties took advantage of the higher rice prices to pay off their debts and collect land taxes more strictly.

sen.j: このような世相の中、それらが元による都市部の治安の悪化、一揆・打ちこわしの激化により不満が高まり、江戸商人への権益を図りすぎたことを理由に贈収賄疑惑を流されるなど、次第に田沼政治への批判が集まっていく。
sen.e: Under such circumstances, people had a grievance due to worsened public peace in urban areas and intensification of uprisings and destructive urban riots, Tanuma's suspicion of bribery was rumored for the reason that he safeguarded interests of merchants in Edo, and the Tanuma politics was criticized gradually.

Under these circumstances, people were unhappy due to worsened public peace in urban areas and the intensification of uprisings and destructive urban riots, Tanuma was suspected of bribery because he safeguarded the interests of merchants in Edo, and Tanuma's politics gradually began to be criticized.

Under these circumstances, people were unhappy due to worsened public peace in urban areas and the intensification of uprisings and destructive urban riots, Tanuma was suspected of bribery because he safeguarded the interests of merchants in Edo, and Tanuma's politics gradually began to be criticized.

sen.j: 外国との貿易を黒字化させて国内の金保有量を高め、さらには北方においてロシア帝国との貿易も行おうとしていたほか、平賀源内などと親交を持ち、蘭学を手厚く保護し、士農工商の別にとらわれない実力主義に基づく人材登用も試みたが、これらの急激な改革が身分制度や朱子学を重視する保守的な幕府閣僚の反発を買い、
sen.e: He tried to expand Japan's trade surplus, increase the possessed quantity of gold in the country, and start trades with the Russian Empire, and made friends with Gennai HIRAGA, etc., and tried to protect Western learning, and take men of talent based on a merit system regardless of Shinokosho (hereditary four-status order consisting of warrior-rulers, peasants, artisans, and merchants), but these sudden reformations provoked a backlash of conservative Cabinet members of the bakufu,
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He tried to expand Japan's trade surplus, increase the quantity of gold possessed in the country, and open trade with the Russian Empire; he also made friends with Gennai HIRAGA and others, tried to protect Western learning, and took on men of talent based on a merit system regardless of Shinokosho (a hereditary four-status order consisting of warrior-rulers, peasants, artisans, and merchants), but these sudden reformations provoked a backlash among the conservative Cabinet members of the bakufu.
sen.cmt: Word choice, word order, grammar, punctuation
sen.e: He tried to expand Japan's trade surplus, increase gold holdings, and open trade with the Russian Empire; he also made friends with Gennai HIRAGA and others, protected Western learning, and took on men of talent based on a merit system regardless of the hereditary four-class order consisting of warrior-rulers, peasants, artisans, and merchants (shinokosho), but these sudden reformations provoked a backlash among conservatives in the shogunate cabinet.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 天明4年（1784年）に息子で若年寄の田沼意知が江戸城内で佐野政言に暗殺されたことを契機とし、権勢が衰え始める。
sen.e: Okitomo TANUMA, his son and wakadoshiyori, was killed by Masakoto SANO in Edo-jo Castle in 1784 and Okitugu began to lose his power.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1784, Masakoto SANO assassinated Okitomo TANUMA, his son and wakadoshiyori, in Edo-jo Castle, and Okitsugu's power began to wane.
sen.cmt: Word choice, word order, grammar, punctuation
sen.e: In 1784, Masakoto SANO assassinated Okitomo TANUMA, his son and vise-senior councillor (wakadoshiyori), in Edo-jo Castle, and Okitsugu's power began to wane.
sen.cmt: 若年寄の訳を変えました。

sen.j: 天明6年（1786年）8月25日、将軍家治が死去。
sen.e: Shogun Ieharu died on August 25, 1786.
Shogun Ieharu died on August 25, 1786.
Shogun Ieharu died on August 25, 1786.

sen.j: 死の直前から「家治の勘気を被った」としてその周辺から遠ざけられていた意次は、将軍の死が秘せられていた間（高貴な人の死は一定期間秘せられるのが通例）に失脚する。
sen.e: Okitsugu was steered away from Ieharu from immediately before his death since 'Ieharu was angry with him', and lost his position while the death of the shogun was hidden (the death of nobles was usually kept secret for some time).

Okitsugu was distanced from Ieharu immediately before his death on the grounds that Ieharu was angry with him, and he lost his position while the death of the shogun was hidden (the death of nobles was usually kept secret for some time).

Okitsugu was distanced from Ieharu immediately before his death on the grounds that Ieharu was angry with him, and he lost his position while the death of the shogun was hidden (the death of nobles was usually kept secret for some time).

sen.j: この動きには、反田沼派や一橋家の策謀があったともされる。
sen.e: It is said that the scheme of anti-Tanuma group and the Hitotsubashi family caused this activity.
It is said that the anti-Tanuma faction and the Hitotsubashi family may have orchestrated this activity.
It is said that the anti-Tanuma faction and the Hitotsubashi family may have orchestrated this activity.

sen.j: 8月27日に老中を辞任させられ、雁間詰に降格。
sen.e: He was resigned from roju and demoted to Karino ma zume.
Tanuma had the post of roju taken from him and was demoted to Karino ma zume.
Tanuma had the post of senior councillor (roju) taken from him and was demoted to one of feudal lords in waiting in the Wild Goose Room of Edo Castle (karino ma zume).
sen.cmt: 雁間詰の訳を変えました。

sen.j: 閏10月5日には家治時代の加増分の2万石を没収され、さらに大坂にある蔵屋敷の財産の没収と江戸屋敷の明け渡しも命じられた。
sen.e: The additional fief of 20000 koku in the Ieharu period was forfeited on leap October 5, and in addition, and he was ordered to give up the property of the Kurayashiki (Warehouse-residence) in Osaka and hand over the Edo residence.

The additional fief of 20,000 koku from the Ieharu period was forfeited on leap October 5, and in addition, he was ordered to give up his Kurayashiki (Warehouse-residence) property in Osaka and hand over his Edo residence.

The additional fief of 20,000 koku from the Ieharu period was forfeited on leap October 5, and in addition, he was ordered to give up his property in his warehouse (kurayashiki) in Osaka and hand over his Edo residence.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: その後、意次は蟄居を命じられ、二度目の減封を受ける。
sen.e: After that, Okitsugu was ordered to stay at home and his territory was diminished again.
After that, Okitsugu was ordered not to leave his home and his territory was diminished again.
After that, Okitsugu was ordered not to leave his home and his territory was diminished again.

sen.j: 相良城は打ち壊し、城内に備蓄されていた金穀は没収と徹底的に処罰された。
sen.e: He was punished severely; the Sagara-jo Castle was destroyed and the money and cereals stored in the castle were forfeited.
He was punished severely: Sagara-jo Castle was destroyed, and the money and grain stored in the castle forfeited.
He was punished severely: Sagara-jo Castle was destroyed, and the money and grain stored in the castle forfeited.

sen.j: 長男の田沼意知は既に死去していて、他の三人の子供は全て養子に出されていたため、孫の田沼意明が陸奥1万石に減転封のうえで家督を継ぐことを許された。
sen.e: Since the first son Okitomo TANUMA was already dead and other three sons were adopted out, a grandchild Okiaki TANUMA was allowed to take over as head of the family provided that the territory was reduced to 10000 koku in the Mutsu province

Since his first son Okitomo TANUMA was already dead and his other three sons were adopted out, his grandson Okiaki TANUMA was allowed to take over as head of the family, provided that their territory was reduced to 10,000 koku in the Mutsu province.

Since his first son Okitomo TANUMA was already dead and his other three sons were adopted out, his grandson Okiaki TANUMA was allowed to take over as head of the family, provided that their territory was reduced to a fief of 10,000 koku in the Mutsu province.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 同じく軽輩から側用人として権力をのぼりつめた柳沢吉保や間部詮房が、辞任のみで処罰は無く家禄も維持し続けたことに比べると最も苛烈な末路となった。
sen.e: This was very severe punishment because Yoshiyasu YANAGISAWA and Akifusa MANABE who were promoted from keihai (a person of low rank) to sobayonin (lord chamberlain) like Okitsugu were only resigned without punishment and kept their fiefs.

This was very severe punishment: Yoshiyasu YANAGISAWA and Akifusa MANABE, who, like Okitsugu, had been promoted from keihai (a person of low rank) to sobayonin (lord chamberlain), were only demoted without punishment and were allowed to keep their fiefs.

This was very severe punishment: Yoshiyasu YANAGISAWA and Akifusa MANABE, who, like Okitsugu, had been promoted from a low rank official to a shogunate chamberlain (sobayonin), were only resigned without punishment and were allowed to keep their fiefs.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 天明8年（1788年）6月24日、死去。
sen.e: He died on June 24, 1788.
He died on June 24, 1788.
He died on June 24, 1788.

sen.j: 享年70。
sen.e: The age at death is 70.
He was 70 years old.
He was 70 years old.

sen.j: 田沼の失脚後から既に悪評が出ており、これは明治以降も引き継がれた。
sen.e: Okitsugu got a bad reputation after he fell from power, and it continued after the Meiji period.
After his fall from power, Okitsugu got a bad reputation which lasted beyond the Meiji period.
After his fall from power, Okitsugu got a bad reputation which lasted beyond the Meiji period.

sen.j: しかし、川路聖謨は「よほどの豪傑」「正直の豪傑」であったと評している。
sen.e: However, Toshiakira KAWAJI described him as a 'great heroic figure' and 'honest heroic figure'.
However, Toshiakira KAWAJI described him as a 'great heroic figure' and 'honest heroic figure'.
However, Toshiakira KAWAJI described him as a 'great heroic figure' and 'honest heroic figure.'

sen.j: 近代には、大正6年（1917年）に辻善之助著『田沼時代』が発表されると、田沼意次＝「賄賂政治家」とされ、田沼悪人説が流通していた。
sen.e: When "Tanuma period (the period when Okitsugu Tanuma led the government for about 20 years during the middle of the Edo period)" written by Zennosuke TSUJI was published in 1917, Okitsugu TANUMA was considered a corruptible statesman, and a Tanuma villain theory was widespead.

When Zennosuke TSUJI's "Tanuma Period (the period when Okitsugu Tanuma led the government for about 20 years during the middle of the Edo period)" was published in 1917, Okitsugu TANUMA was considered a corruptible statesman, and a Tanuma villain theory was widespead.
When Zennosuke TSUJI's "Tanuma Period" was published in 1917, Okitsugu TANUMA was considered a corruptible statesman, and a Tanuma villain theory was widespead.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: ただし、辻は政策の進歩性などについて大きく評価しており、開明的政治家としての再評価も高まっている。
sen.e: However, Tsuji valued progressivity of his policies and he was reevaluated as a progressive statesman.
However, Tsuji valued the progressiveness of Tanuma's policies, and reevaluated him as a progressive statesman.
However, Tsuji valued the progressiveness of Tanuma's policies, and reevaluated him as a progressive statesman.

sen.j: また、大石慎三郎らは「賄賂政治家」という悪評は反対派によって政治的に作られていったとしている。
sen.e: Shinsaburo OISHI and others considered that the bad reputation of the corruptible politician was given politically by the opponents.
Shinsaburo OISHI and others considered that his bad reputation as a corruptible politician was a political creation of his opponents.
Shinsaburo OISHI and others considered that his bad reputation as a corruptible politician was a political creation of his opponents.

sen.j: これらの説によると、田沼悪人説の根拠となる史料も田沼失脚後に政敵たちにより口述されたもので、辻の著作においては信憑性が検証されていないとしている。
sen.e: According to this theory, the historical document that was considered proof of the Tanuma villain theory was created by political opponents after Tanuma fell from power and its credibility was not verified in the documentation of Tsuji.

According to this theory, the historical document that was considered proof of the Tanuma villain theory was created by his political opponents after Tanuma fell from power, and its credibility was not verified in Tsuji's documentation.

According to this theory, the historical document that was considered proof of the Tanuma villain theory was created by his political opponents after Tanuma fell from power, and its credibility was not verified in Tsuji's documentation.

sen.j: また、仙台藩主伊達重村からの賄賂を田沼が拒絶したという史料の存在、逆に田沼を非難していた松平定信さえも田沼にいやいや金品を贈ったと書き残していることなどをその論拠としている。
sen.e: The reason is that there is a historical material that Tanuma declined a bribe from the lord of the Sendai domain, but Shigemura DATE and Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA who blamed Tanuma wrote that he had presented Tanuma with money and goods reluctantly.

The reason is that there is historical evidence that Tanuma declined a bribe from Shigemura DATE, the lord of the Sendai domain, while even Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, who criticized Tanuma, wrote that he had presented Tanuma with money and goods reluctantly.
sen.cmt: Word order, word choice, punctuation, grammar
sen.e: The reason is that there is historical evidence that Tanuma declined a bribe from Shigemura DATE, the lord of the Sendai domain, while even Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, who criticized Tanuma, wrote that he had presented Tanuma with money and goods reluctantly.

sen.j: また贈収賄は江戸時代通じての問題で、それ自体も近代以後に比べればかえって少なかったという説も唱えられている。
sen.e: Bribery was a problem during the Edo period and there is a theory that says that it was less frequent than one at modern times.
Bribery was a problem during the Edo period, and there is a theory that says it was less frequent than it is in modern times.
Bribery was a problem during the Edo period, and there is a theory that says it was less frequent than it is in modern times.

sen.j: なお、田沼の没後松平定信によって私財のほとんどを没収されたが、そのときには「塵一つでない」といわれるほど財産がなかったとの逸話もある。
sen.e: The private property of Tanuma was forfeited by Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA after his death, but Tanuma had little property and it was said that 'there was no dust'.
Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA confiscated Tanuma's private property after his death, but it is said that Tanuma had so little property that 'there wasn't so much as a dust mote'.
sen.cmt: Word choice, word order, punctuation, grammar
sen.e: Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA confiscated Tanuma's private property after his death, but it is said that Tanuma had so little property that 'there wasn't so much as a dust mote'.

sen.j: 田沼失脚後に老中となった松平定信ら譜代・親藩による寛政の改革が始まり、意次の政策は否定される。
sen.e: The Kansei Reforms were started by hereditary daimyo and the daimyo of feudal domains owned by Tokugawa family branches, such as Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA who became roju after the downfall of Tanuma, and the policies of Okitsugu were denied.

The Kansei Reforms were started by hereditary daimyo and the daimyo of feudal domains owned by branches of the Tokugawa family (including people such as Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA, who became roju after the downfall of Tanuma), and the policies of Okitsugu were negated.
The Kansei Reforms were started by feudal lords of hereditary shogunate direct retainer (fudai daimyo) and feudal lords of the Tokugawa family, and the policies of Okitsugu were negated.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 11代将軍徳川家斉の大御所時代に、水野忠友の子水野忠成と、田沼意次の四男田沼意正らによって重商主義に基づく政策は一時見直されるが、大御所家斉の浪費のためほとんど効果を上げることはできなかった。
sen.e: In the period of Ogosho (leading or influential figure) of the 11th shogun Ienari TOKUGAWA, Tadaakira MIZUNO, son of Tadatomo MIZUNO, and Okimasa TANUMA, the fourth son of Okitsugu TANUMA, reevaluated the policies based on Mercantilism, but they could not achieve little effects due to extravagance of Ogosho Ienari.

In the Ogosho (leading or influential figure) period of the 11th shogun Ienari TOKUGAWA, Tadaakira MIZUNO, the son of Tadatomo MIZUNO, and Okimasa TANUMA, the fourth son of Okitsugu TANUMA, temporarily reevaluated policies based on mercantilism, but due to the extravagance of Ogosho Ienari, they produced little effect.
sen.cmt: Word choice, word order, grammar, punctuation
sen.e: In the Ogosho period, where the retired (but still de facto) shogun (ogosho) of Ienari TOKUGAWA, the 11th shogun, held power, Tadaakira MIZUNO, the son of Tadatomo MIZUNO, and Okimasa TANUMA, the fourth son of Okitsugu TANUMA, temporarily reevaluated policies based on mercantilism, but due to the extravagance of Ogosho Ienari, they produced little effect.
sen.cmt: 大御所政治の訳を変えました。

sen.j: 松平定信は庶民の着物の柄まで制限するほどの質素倹約な方針だったので、良くも悪くも世俗的な田沼意次の政治を懐かしむ声も見られた。
sen.e: Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA carried out a policy of simplicity and frugality so that he restricted even patterns of kimono of the common people, and some looked back to the worldly politics of Okitsugu TANUMA with nostalgia for better or for worse.

Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA stuck to a policy of simplicity and frugality to the extent that he restricted even the patterns on the kimono of the common people, and, for better or for worse, some looked back on the worldly politics of Okitsugu TANUMA with nostalgia.

Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA stuck to a policy of simplicity and frugality to the extent that he restricted even the patterns on the kimono of the common people, and, for better or for worse, some looked back on the worldly politics of Okitsugu TANUMA with nostalgia.

sen.j: この時期流行った落首として次の二つがある。
sen.e: Two rakushu (lampoons) shown below became popular at this time.
Two rakushu (lampoons) shown below became popular at this time.
Two lampoons shown below became popular at this time.

sen.j: 定信の就任当初は前者の歌が流行ったが、やがて改革が厳しすぎるとわかると後者の歌に取って代わられた。
sen.e: When Sadanobu assumed his position, the former poem became popular, but when the reform was proved to be too strict, the latter became popular instead.
When Sadanobu assumed his position, the former poem grew popular, but when the reform proved too strict, the latter became popular instead.
When Sadanobu assumed his position, the former poem grew popular, but when the reform proved too strict, the latter became popular instead.

sen.j: 田や沼やよごれた御世を改めて 清くぞすめる白河の水
sen.e: Rice fields, ponds and the dirty imperial reign are reformed and cleaned like the water of Shirakawa.
Rice fields, ponds and the dirty imperial reign are reformed and cleansed like the water of Shirakawa.
Rice fields, ponds and the dirty imperial reign are reformed and cleansed like the water of Shirakawa.

sen.j: 白河の清きに魚も住みかねて もとの濁りの田沼恋しき
sen.e: Even fish cannot live in the clean water of Shirakawa and old dirty rice fields and ponds are yearned for.
Even fish cannot live in the clean water of Shirakawa and old dirty rice fields and ponds are yearned for.
Even fish cannot live in the clean water of Shirakawa and old dirty rice fields and ponds are yearned for.

sen.j: 現在の田沼論はどちらかといえば「老中としての田沼」を論ずるのがメインとなっている感があるが、相良藩主としての田沼に関しては街道や港の拡張、防火対策（相良で起こった大火の後、藁葺きの家はことごとく瓦葺にするよう令を発している）、殖産興業などきわめて正統的で当を得た施政を行っている。
sen.e: The present Tanuma theory mainly discusses 'Tanuma as roju', but he carried out very orthodoxical and reasonable policies, such as expansion of roads and ports, fire prevention measures (an order was issued to replace straw-thatched roofs with tile roofs after a great fire in Sagara) and encouragement of new industry.

The present Tanuma theory mainly discusses 'Tanuma as roju', but as lord of Sagara domain, he carried out very orthodoxical and reasonable policies, including the expansion of roads and ports, fire prevention measures (an order was issued to replace straw-thatched roofs with tile roofs after a great fire in Sagara), and encouragement of new industry.
sen.cmt: Punctuation, inserted missing translation, word choice
sen.e: At present Tanuma was mainly discussed in the aspect of 'Tanuma as a senior councillor (roju),' but as a feudal lord of Sagara domain, he carried out very orthodoxical and reasonable policies, including the expansion of roads and ports, fire prevention measures (an order was issued to replace straw-thatched roofs with tile roofs after a great fire in Sagara), and encouragement of new industry.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: ちなみに田沼意次を抜擢した徳川家治については、かつては田沼とワンセットで暗君との評価がなされてきた。
sen.e: Ieharu TOKUGAWA who promoted Okitsugu TANUMA was evaluated as a foolish ruler due to the relationship with Tanuma.
Ieharu TOKUGAWA, who had promoted Okitsugu TANUMA, was deemed a foolish ruler due to his relationship with Tanuma.
Ieharu TOKUGAWA, who had promoted Okitsugu TANUMA, was deemed a foolish ruler due to his relationship with Tanuma.

sen.j: 田沼に対する悪人説が覆った現在において、その田沼を抜擢した事を高く評価する意見が一部に出始めているものの、未だ家治については評価が覆っていないのが現状である。
sen.e: The Tanuma villain theory has been denied today, and some highly evaluate the promotion of Tanuma, but the evaluation of Ieharu has not changed.
The Tanuma villain theory has been denied today, and some think highly of Tanuma's promotion, but the evaluation of Ieharu has not changed.
The Tanuma villain theory has been denied today, and some think highly of Ieharu for Tanuma's promotion, but the evaluation of Ieharu has not changed yet.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: ただし、徳川綱吉、徳川吉宗以降の将軍専制政治体制（将軍が側用人・御用取次を通じて政治を行う体制）において家治が積極的な政治関与を行わなかったことが、田沼が強力な政治的権力を握ることになった要因のひとつでもある。
sen.e: One of the reasons that Tanuma gained strong political power is that Ieharu did not take part in politics actively in the shogun tyranny political system (in which the shogun administers the affairs of state) after Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA and Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.

One of the reasons that Tanuma gained strong political power is that Ieharu did not actively take part in politics via the shogun dictatorship political system (in which the shogun administers the affairs of state) after Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA and Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.

One of the reasons that Tanuma gained strong political power is that Ieharu did not actively take part in politics via the shogun dictatorship political system (in which the shogun administers the affairs of state through chamberlains [sobayonin] and attendants [toritsugi]) after Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA and Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: ハーバード大学のジョン・ホイットニー・ホールは「tanuma Okitsugu」において「意次は近代日本の先駆者」と評価している。
sen.e: John Whitney Hall of Harvard University evaluated that 'Okitsugu was a pioneer of modern Japan' in tanuma Okitsugu'.
John Whitney Hall of Harvard University judged Okitsugu to be 'a pioneer of modern Japan' in 'Tanuma Okitsugu'.
John Whitney Hall of Harvard University judged Okitsugu to be 'a pioneer of modern Japan' in 'Tanuma Okitsugu'.

sen.j: 仙台藩医の工藤平助は、迫りくる北方の大国ロシアの脅威に備える為「赤蝦夷風説考」を天明3年（1783年）、当時の幕府老中、田沼意次に献上した。
sen.e: Heisuke KUDO, a doctor of the Sendai domain, presented 'Akaezo-fusetsu-ko (A study of rumors about Russians)' to Okitsugu TANUMA, then bakufu roju, in 1783 to prepare for threats of Russia, a large country at the north.
sen.cmt: 赤蝦夷風説考は、'Akaezo-fusetsu-ko (A study of rumors about Russians)'と訳しました。
sen.e: Heisuke KUDO, a doctor of the Sendai domain, presented Okitsugu TANUMA, then bakufu rojo, with 'Akaezo-fusetsu-ko (A study of rumors about Russians)' in 1783 to prepare for threats from Russia, the large country to the north.

Heisuke KUDO, a doctor of the Sendai domain, presented Okitsugu TANUMA, then shogunate senior councillor (rojo), with ' (A study of rumors about Russians (Akaezo-fusetsu-ko)' in 1783 to prepare for threats from Russia, a northern large country.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: このことが田沼の蝦夷地開発の原点になったといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that this formed the basis of development of Ezochi (inhabited area of Ainu).
It is said that this formed the basis of the development of Ezochi (area inhabited by Ainu).
It is said that this formed the basis of the development of Ezo (present Hokkaido).
sen.cmt: 蝦夷地の訳を変えました。

sen.j: 田沼は、蝦夷地調査団に、まず、経世家の本多利明を招聘しようとしたが、辞退されてしまう。
sen.e: Tanuma tried to appoint Toshiaki HONDA as a member of the Ezo research group, but he declined this offer.
Tanuma tried to appoint Toshiaki HONDA as a member of the Ezochi research group, but he declined the offer.
Tanuma tried to appoint Toshiaki HONDA as a member of the Ezo research group, but he declined the offer.
sen.cmt: 蝦夷地の訳を変えました。

sen.j: 代わりに本多から推薦されたのが最上徳内であった。
sen.e: Honda recommended Tokunai MOGAMI instead.
Honda recommended Tokunai MOGAMI instead.
Honda recommended Tokunai MOGAMI instead.

sen.j: 発明家として有名だった平賀源内のことを田沼は大変、気に入っていたらしい。
sen.e: Tanuma seemed to like Gennai HIRAGA who was a famous inventor.
Tanuma seemed to like Gennai HIRAGA, a famous inventor, very much.
Tanuma seemed to like Gennai HIRAGA, a famous inventor, very much.

sen.j: 田沼は平賀をオランダ商人のいる出島に遊学させた事もあった。
sen.e: Tanuma let him study in Dejima where Dutch merchants lived.
Tanuma let him study in Dejima, where Dutch merchants lived.
Tanuma let him study in Dejima, where Dutch merchants lived.

sen.j: ところが、平賀源内が殺人事件を起こしてしまった為、田沼は彼とのつながりを全面的に否定した。
sen.e: Since Gennai HIRAGA killed a man, however, Tanuma denied his connections with Haraga.
However, Gennai HIRAGA killed a man, so Tanuma denied all connection to Hiraga.
However, Gennai HIRAGA killed a man, so Tanuma denied all connection to Hiraga.

sen.j: もし、平賀が殺人事件を起こしていなければ、田沼は蝦夷地開発の責任者を平賀にやらせただろう、とも言われている。
sen.e: It is said that if Hiraga had not killed the man, Tanuma would have assigned him to a person responsible for the development of Ezochi.
It is said that if Hiraga had not killed the man, Tanuma would have assigned him as one responsible for the development of Ezochi.
It is said that if Hiraga had not killed the man, Tanuma would have assigned him as one responsible for the development of Ezo (present Hokkaido).
sen.cmt: 蝦夷地の訳を変えました。

sen.j: 貨幣経済を振興しようと思ったきっかけは、徳川吉宗による政治にあった。
sen.e: The politics of Yoshimune TOKUGAWA made it an occasion to promote the monetary economy.
The politics of Yoshimune TOKUGAWA provided an occasion to promote a monetary economy.
The politics of Yoshimune TOKUGAWA provided an occasion to promote a monetary economy.

sen.j: 当時、米相場の乱高下に頭を悩ます吉宗を身近で見て、田沼は日本に貨幣経済を普及させて問題を解決できないか、と考えたという。
sen.e: Since Yoshimune was worried about violent fluctuations of rice price, Tanuma considered whether the problem could be solved by promoting the monetary economy in Japan.
Yoshimune was concerned about the violently fluctuating price of rice, and it is said that Tanuma wondered whether the problem could be solved by promoting a monetary economy in Japan.
Yoshimune was concerned about the violently fluctuating price of rice, and it is said that Tanuma wondered whether the problem could be solved by promoting a monetary economy in Japan.

sen.j: 田沼の経済政策は、市中に流れる貨幣の流通速度をコントロールして経済を活性化させる目的があったとする説が有力である。
sen.e: There is a dominant theory that the economic policies of Tanuma were intended to control the distribution speed of money in the market.
The dominant theory is that Tanuma's economic policies were intended to control the distribution speed of money in the market.
The dominant explanation is that Tanuma's economic revitalization policies were intended to control the distribution speed of money in the market.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 吉宗時代の質素倹約をいつまでも続けても、それは今風に言えば「貯蓄、タンス預金の奨励」であり、裏返せば「消費の低迷」であった。
sen.e: If simplicity and frugality was continued as in the Yoshimune period, it 'promoted saving', causing 'stagnant consumption'.
If the simplicity and frugality of the Yoshimune period were continued, they would only, in modern terms, 'promote saving', which would cause 'stagnant consumption'.
sen.cmt: Word choice, word order, punctuation, grammar
sen.e: If the simplicity and frugality of the Yoshimune period were continued, they would only, in modern terms, 'promotion of saving and keeping money under the mattress,' which would cause 'a continuing consumer slump.'
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: それでは、いつまでたっても内需（景気）は刺激されないし、幕府の財政も増えない。
sen.e: Domestic demands (economic conditions) would not be stimulated and the financial affairs of the bakufu would not improve.
Domestic demand (economic conditions) would not be stimulated and the financial affairs of the bakufu would not improve.
Domestic demand (economic conditions) would not be stimulated and the financial affairs of the shogunate government would not improve.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 財政が増えなければ、行政の仕事も増えないし、幕府の公共事業も自由にできない。
sen.e: If the financial affairs did not improve, administration work did not increase and public enterprises of the bakufu could not be undertaken freely.
If financial affairs did not improve, administration work would not increase and the bakufu's public enterprises could not be undertaken freely.
If financial affairs did not improve, administration work would not increase and the shogunate government could not undertake public enterprises freely.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: そのため、広く人材や献策を取り入れたが、「山師」の跋扈する時代を生むこととなった。
sen.e: Thus, persons and recommended proposals were adopted, but a lot of speculators appeared.
For that reason, persons and recommended proposals were adopted, but it produced an era in which many speculators appeared.
For that reason, persons and recommended proposals were adopted, but it produced an era in which many speculators appeared.

sen.j: 彼の行った諸政策を金権政治の一言で切り捨てる向きもあるが、「贈収賄の蔓延がついて回る重商政策を行わずにどうすれば当時破綻寸前だった幕府財政を立て直せたのか？」との問いに万人を納得させる方法論が未だ提起されていないのが実情である。
sen.e: The policies carried out by him were often criticized as money politics, but there are no reasonable answers to a question 'how the nearly bankrupt financial affairs of the bakufu at that time could be recovered without carrying out Mercantilism policies which resulted in bribery.

The policies he executed were often criticized as "money politics", but so far, no reasonable answer has been provided for the question of how the nearly-bankrupt financial affairs of the bakufu at the time could have been recovered without carrying out mercantilism policies which resulted in bribery.
sen.cmt: Word choice, word order, grammar, punctuation
sen.e: The policies he executed were often criticized as 'money politics,' but so far, no reasonable answer has been provided for the question of how the nearly-bankrupt financial affairs of the shogunate government at the time could have been recovered without carrying out mercantilism policies which resulted in bribery.
sen.cmt: "を'とし、,の位置を変えました。

sen.j: 田沼意次の在任中に幕府財政の貨幣収入が増えたことは特筆に価する。
sen.e: It is important to remember that the monetary income increased in the financial affairs of the bakufu when Okitsugu TANUMA was on duty.
It is important to note that the monetary income of the bakufu finances increased when Okitsugu TANUMA was on duty.
It is important to note that the monetary income of the shogunate finances increased when Okitsugu TANUMA was on duty.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

tit.e: Development of Ezochi (inhabited area of Ainu)
Development of Ezochi (an area inhabited by Ainu)
tit.cmt: 蝦夷地の訳を変えました。

sen.j: 田沼は、蝦夷地を調べる為に幕府の探検隊を作った。
sen.e: Tanuma organized an expedition team of the bakufu to investigate Ezochi.
Tanuma organized an expedition team to investigate Ezochi for the bakufu.
Tanuma organized an expedition team to investigate Ezo (present Hokkaido) for the government.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: メンバーには、青島俊蔵、最上徳内、大石逸平、庵原弥六、などがいた。
sen.e: Its members include Toshizo AOSHIMA, Tokunai MOGAMI, Ippei OISHI, Yaroku ANBARA.
Its members included Toshizo AOSHIMA, Tokunai MOGAMI, Ippei OISHI and Yaroku ANBARA.
Its members included Toshizo AOSHIMA, Tokunai MOGAMI, Ippei OISHI and Yaroku ANBARA.

sen.j: また、蝦夷地の調査開発をすすめる事務方には、勘定奉行松本秀持、勘定組頭土山宗次郎などがいた。
sen.e: Clerks for investigation and development of Ezochi included kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance) Hidemochi MATSUMOTO and kanjo kumigashira (a head of the group) Sojiro TSUCHIYAMA
Clerks for the investigation and development of Ezochi included kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance) Hidemochi MATSUMOTO and kanjo kumigashira (a head of the group) Sojiro TSUCHIYAMA.

Clerks for the investigation and development of Ezo included the chief commissioner of finance (kanjo bugyo) Hidemochi MATSUMOTO and the head of the accounting section (kanjo kumigashira) Sojiro TSUCHIYAMA.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 田沼は、幕府の潤沢な財政を蝦夷地開発に注ぎ込んだが、あまり良い結果は出せなかった。
sen.e: Tanuma spent plenty of money of the bakufu on the development of Ezochi, with little results.
Tanuma spent plenty of the bakufu's money on the development of Ezochi, with scant results.
Tanuma spent plenty of the government money on the development of Ezo, with scant results.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 田沼失脚後、松平定信は、田沼の政策である蝦夷地開発を中止し責任者を厳罰にしたが、その頃、蝦夷地近海に頻繁に現われるロシア艦船に不安を感じ、蝦夷地の天領化、北方警備に幕府として取り組み始めた。
sen.e: After the downfall of Tanuma, his policy of development of Ezochi was abandoned and the responsible persons were punished, but the bakufu was anxious about frequent appearances of Russian ships on the sea near Ezochi, made Ezochi a shogunal demesne and defense the northern land.

After Tanuma's downfall, Ezochi development policy was abandoned and the persons responsible punished, but the bakufu, anxious about frequent appearances of Russian ships on the sea near Ezochi, made Ezochi a shogunal demesne and defense against the northern land.
sen.cmt: Word order, word choice, punctuation, grammar
sen.e: After Tanuma's downfall, the Ezo development policy was abandoned and the persons responsible punished, but the shogunate government, anxious about frequent appearances of Russian ships on the sea near Ezo, made Ezo a shogunal demesne for the defense of the northern land.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

tit.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 享保19年（1734年） - 徳川家重の小姓となる。
sen.e: 1734 - Became a pageboy of Ieshige TOKUGAWA.
1734 - Became a pageboy of Ieshige TOKUGAWA.
1734 - Became a pageboy of Ieshige TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 元文2年（1737年） - 従五位主殿寮に叙任。
sen.e: 1737 - Invested to jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) Tonomoryo (Bureau of Grounds).
1737 - Given the title of jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) Tonomoryo (Bureau of Grounds).
1737 - Given the title of the junior fifth rank of the Imperial Palace Keeper's Bureau.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 延享4年（1747年） - 小姓組番頭格。
sen.e: 1747 - Head of page office.
1747 - Head of page office.
1747 - Head of page office.

sen.j: 寛延元年（1748年）閏10月1日 - 小姓組番頭、奥勤兼務に異動。
sen.e: Leap October 1, 1748 - Changed to the head of page office, confidential service.
sen.cmt: 奥勤兼務はconfidential serviceと訳しました。
sen.e: Leap October 1, 1748 - Changed to the head of page office, confidential service.
Leap October 1, 1748 - Changed to the head of page office and concurrently a servant in the domestic quarters of Edo Castle.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 石高1400石加増。
sen.e: A crop yield of 1400 koku was added.
A crop yield of 1,400 koku was added.
A fief of 1,400 koku of rice was added.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: それまでは、小姓組番頭格奥勤。
sen.e: Head of page office, confidential service
Until then, head of page office, confidential service
Until then, the head of page office and concurrently a servant in the domestic quarters of Edo Castle.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 宝暦元年（1751年）4月18日 - 御側御用取次側衆に異動。
sen.e: April 18, 1751 - Changed to attendant official business toritsugi (an attendant who serves Shogun by informing of a visitor and convey the message) Osobashu.
April 18, 1751 - Changed to attendant official business toritsugi (an attendant who serves the Shogun by informing him of visitors and conveying their messages) Osobashu.
April 18, 1751 - Changed to one of close shogunate attendants to informing him of visitors and conveying messages (toritsugi osobashu).
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 宝暦5年（1755年） - 石高3000石加増。
sen.e: 1755 - A crop yield of 1400 koku was added.
1755 - A crop yield of 1,400 koku was added.
1755 - A fief of 3,000 koku of rice was added.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 宝暦8年（1758年） - 石高5000石加増。
sen.e: 1758 - A crop yield of 5000 koku was added.
1758 - A crop yield of 5,000 koku was added.
1758 - A fief of 5,000 koku of rice was added.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 1万石の大名となる。
sen.e: He became a daimyo with ten thousands Goku crop yields.
He became a daimyo with crop yields of 10,000 koku.
He became a feudal lord (daimyo) with a fief of 10,000 koku of rice.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.e: 1762 - A crop yield of 5000 koku was added.
1762 - A crop yield of 5,000 koku was added.
1762 - A fief of 5,000 koku of rice was added.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 明和4年（1767年）7月1日 - 側用人に異動。
sen.e: July 1, 1767 - Transferred to sobayonin (lord chamberlain).
July 1, 1767 - Transferred to sobayonin (lord chamberlain).
July 1, 1767 - Transferred to a shogunate chamberlain (sobayonin).
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 従四位に昇叙。
sen.e: Promoted to Jnior fourth court rank.
Promoted to junior fourth court rank.
Promoted to junior fourth court rank.

sen.j: 石高5000石加増。
sen.e: A crop yield of 5000 koku was added.
A crop yield of 5,000 koku was added.
A fief of 5,000 koku of rice was added.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 遠江国相良2万石の領主となる。
sen.e: Became the feudal lord of Sagara of the Totomi province with a fief of 20000 koku.
Became the feudal lord of Sagara, Totomi province, with a fief of 20,000 koku.
Became the feudal lord of Sagara, Totomi province, with a fief of 20,000 koku.

sen.j: 明和6年（1769年）8月18日 - 老中格に異動し、側用人兼務。
sen.e: August 18, 1769 - Changed to roju and doubled as sobayonin (lord chamberlain).
August 18, 1769 - Transferred to roju while also serving as sobayonin (lord chamberlain).
August 18, 1769 - Transferred to a senior councillor (roju) and concurrently a shogunate chamberlain (sobayonin).
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 侍従兼任。
sen.e: Doubled as palace staff.
Doubled as palace staff.
Served concurrently as a grand chamberlain (jiju).
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 石高5000石加増。
sen.e: A crop yield of 5000 koku was added.
A crop yield of 5,000 koku was added.
A fief of 5,000 koku of rice was added.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 明和9年（1772年）1月15日 - 老中に異動。
sen.e: January 15, 1772 - Changed to roju.
January 15, 1772 - Transferred to roju.
January 15, 1772 - Transferred to a senior councillor (roju).
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 石高5000石加増。
sen.e: A crop yield of 5000 koku was added.
A crop yield of 5,000 koku was added.
A fief of 5,000 koku of rice was added.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 安永6年（1777年）4月21日 - 石高7000石加増。
sen.e: April 21, 1781 - A crop yield of 7000 koku was added.
April 21, 1781 - A crop yield of 7,000 koku was added.
April 21, 1777 - A fief of 7,000 koku of rice was added.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 天明元年（1781年）7月15日 - 石高1万石加増。
sen.e: July 15, 1781 - A crop yield of 10000 koku was added.
July 15, 1781 - A crop yield of 10,000 koku was added.
July 15, 1781 - A fief of 10,000 koku of rice was added.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 天明5年（1785年）1月21日 - 石高1万石加増。
sen.e: January 21, 1785 - A crop yield of 10000 koku was added.
January 21, 1785 - A crop yield of 10,000 koku was added.
January 21, 1785 - A fief of 10,000 koku was added.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 合計石高5万7000石となる。
sen.e: The total crop yield became 57000 koku.
The total crop yield became 57,000 koku.
The total fief became 57,000 koku of rice.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 天明6年（1786年）8月27日 - 老中依願御役御免。
sen.e: August 27, 1786 - Retired from roju.
August 27, 1786 - Retired from roju.
August 27, 1786 - Retired from a senior councillor (roju).
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 石高2万石召上げ。
sen.e: A crop yield of 20000 koku was forfeited.
A crop yield of 20,000 koku was forfeited.
A fief of 20,000 koku of rice was forfeited.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 雁之間詰。
sen.e: Karinomatsume (feudal lord that Karino-ma room in Edo-jo castle was set as his station)
Karinomatsume (a feudal lord for whom the Karino-ma room in Edo-jo castle was set as a station)
Demoted to one of feudal lords in waiting in the Wild Goose Room of Edo Castle (karino ma zume)
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 天明7年（1787年）10月2日 - 石高3万7000石召上げ。
sen.e: October 2, 1787 - A crop yield of 37000 koku was forfeited.
October 2, 1787 - A crop yield of 37,000 koku was forfeited.
October 2, 1787 - A fief of 37,000 koku of rice was forfeited.
sen.cmt: 左記のように変更しました。

sen.j: 蟄居となる。
sen.e: He was confined to his house.
He was confined to his house.
He was confined to his house.
